p.seg: Bei den topographischen Bestimmungen, die hier, wenn auch dem Hauptzwecke des Buches fremd, doch unentbehrlich waren, um eine Oertlichkeit zu erlangen, innerhalb deren sich die Erzählung bewegen könne, habe ich wohl gefühlt, wie misslich für den, welcher der eigenen Anschauung entbehrend nur fremden Berichten folgen kann, besonders eine in’s Einzelne gehende Beschreibung ist. Ich glaube indessen die wichtigsten Werke, welche von der Topographie dieses Theils von Griechenland handeln, so sorgfältig und zugleich so behutsam benutzt zu haben, dass ich nicht fürchten darf, es habe sich eine bedeutende Unrichtigkeit eingeschlichen, die zwar für die Hauptsache immer unwesentlich sein würde, deren Entfernung doch aber wünschenswerth bleibt. Für diesen Zweck habe ich ausser den Nachrichten von Strabo und Pausanias besonders gebraucht: Gell Itinerary of the Morea, Lond. 1817; Dodwell A classical and topographical tour through Greece, Lond. 1819, t. II; Leake, Travels in the Morea, Lond. 1830, t. III; Pouqueville Voyage dans la Grèce, Par. 1820, t. IV; und die Angaben der Expédition de Morée, Par. 1832 ff. t. II u. III. — Von Kleonä sagt

I believe, however, to have used the most important works dealing with the topography of this part of Greece so carefully and at the same time so carefully that I cannot fear that a significant inaccuracy has crept in, which would always be irrelevant for the main thing, but whose removal nevertheless remains desirable. For this purpose, in addition to the reports of Strabo and Pausanias, I have used in particular:

cit.quote: Κλεωναὶ δ᾽ εἰσὶ πόλισμα ἐπὶ τῇ ὁδῷ κείμενον τῇ ἐξ Ἄργους εἰς Κόρινθον. ἐπὶ λόφου περιοιχουμένου πανταχόϑεν καὶ τετειχισμένου καλῶς· ὥστ᾽ οἰκείως εἰρῆσϑαί μοι δοκεῖ τὸ ἐῠκτιμένας Κλεωνάς (Iliad. II,570).

Cleonae is a small town located on the road from Argos to Corinth. It is built on a hill surrounded on all sides by a wall and is well fortified; so I think the phrase "well-built Cleonae" was aptly used.

In ancient times, there were two roads from Cleonae to Argos:
Pausan. II, 15, 1: ἐκ Κλεωνῶν δέ εἴσιν ἐς Ἄργος ὁδοὶ δύο. ἡ μὲν ἀνδράσιν εὐζώνοις, καὶ ἐστὶν ἐπίτομος. ἡ δὲ ἐπὶ τοῦ καλουμένου Τρητοῦ στενὴ μὲν καὶ αὐτὴ περιεχόντων ὁρῶν, ὀχήμασι δέ ἐστιν ὅμως ἐπιτηδειοτέρα:
There are two roads from Cleonae to Argos. One is suitable for lightly-armed men and is a shortcut. The other passes through the so-called Tretus and is itself narrow since it is bounded by mountains, yet is somehow more suitable for vehicles.

However, it is not possible to determine with certainty which of these roads, or both, is the Kontoporia mentioned by Polybius XVI, 16 and Athenaeus as leading from Corinth to Mycenae.
Ottfried Müller takes it to be the former (Dorier Th. I, S. 71; cf. G. 6. A. 1832, S. 130). On the other hand, Leake t. III, p. 328 finds it more likely that the shorter path over Aion Oros (ἅγιον ὄρος) is meant. One of the three reasons he gives for this is that the cold spring mentioned by Athenaeus, for which the Kontoporia is named, was located on a hilltop, which is difficult to understand from the former carriage road.
[Bursian B. II, S. 38 remarks about the carriage road: "The carriage road ran from the valley out southwestwards to the western part of Tretus and crossed it, gradually ascending, in a narrow pass, in which one can still recognize in some places the ruts cut into the rock floor." The footpath mentioned by Pausanias leads him from the valley to the plain of Argos past the village of Hagios Basilios on the northern slope of Tretus. Neither Curtius a. a. O. S. 513 nor Bursian S. 9 identifies the Kontoporia with these roads, but both describe it as the shortest, straight line connection between Corinth and Argos. Cf. Ross Reisen und Reiserouten in Griechenland I, S. 25].

Von Kleonä führten im Alterthume zwei Wege nach Argos: Pausan. II, 15, 1: ἐκ Κλεωνῶν δέ εἴσιν ἐς Ἄργος ὁδοὶ δύο. ἡ μὲν ἀνδράσιν εὐζώνοις, καὶ ἐστὶν ἐπίτομος. ἡ δὲ ἐπὶ τοῦ καλουμένου Τρητοῦ στενὴ μὲν καὶ αὐτὴ περιεχόντων ὁρῶν, ὀχήμασι δέ ἐστιν ὅμως ἐπιτηδειοτέρα:

ob aber einer von diesen und welcher die von Polybius XVI, 16 und
Athenaeus erwähnte von Korinth
Athenaeus ΙΙ, 19 ἔγγιστα πρὸς δύσεις χειμερινάς
closest to the winter setting [of the sun]
nach Mykenä führende Κοντοπορία war, darüber sind die Meinungen getheilt. Ottfr. Müller nimmt sie für ersteren (Dorier Th. I, S. 71; vgl. G. 6. A. 1832, S. 130); dagegen findet es Leake t. III, p. 328 wahrscheinlicher, dass damit der heutige kürzere Weg über Aion Oros (ἅγιον ὄρος) gemeint sei; und von den drei Gründen, die er dafür anführt, ist allerdings der von Bedeutung, dass die kalte Quelle, um derenwillen Ath. l. c. der Κοντοπορία gedenkt, auf der Höhe ( κατὰ τὴν ἀκρώρειαν
on the hilltop) lag, was sich von jenem Fahrwege kaum verstehen lässt.
[Ueber den Fahrweg bemerkt Bursian B. II, S. 38: „Die Fahrstrasse zog sich vom Thale aus südwestwürts nach dem westlichen Theile des Tretos und durchschnitt denselben, allmälig aufsteigend, in einem Engpasse, in welchem man noch an einigen Stellen die in den Felsenboden eingeschnittenen Fahrgeleise erkennt.“ Den von Pausanius erwähnten Fusspfad lässt er am nördlichen Abhange des Tretos beim Dorfe Hagios Basilios vorüber vom Thale nach der Ebene von Argos führen. Die Kontoporia dagegen identificirt weder Curtius a. a. O. S. 513, noch Bursian S. 9 mit diesen Wegen, sondern beide bezeichnen sie als den kürzesten, geradlinigen Verbindungspfad zwischen Korinth und Argos. Vergl. Ross Reisen und Reiserouten in Griechenland I, S. 25].

For comparison, let the description that Kybele gives of Theagenes be given here, from which the description of Charicles is almost literally taken.
Heliod. Aethiop. VII, 10: εὑρύς τις ἦν τὰ στέρνα καὶ τοὺς ὥμους, καὶ τὸν αὐχένα ὄρϑιον καὶ ἐλεύϑερον ὑπὲρ τοὺς ἄλλους αἴρων, καὶ εἰς κορυφὴν τοὺς ἅπαντas ὑπερέχων, γλαυκιῶν τὸ βλέμμα καὶ ἑπέραστον ἅμα καὶ γοργὸν προσβλέπων, ἡ καταβόστρυχός που πάντως ἐκεῖνος, τὴν παρειὰν ἄρτι ξανϑῷ τῷ ἰούλῳ περιστέφων :
He was broad in the chest and shoulders, holding his neck upright and free above the others, and overtopping them all in height, blue-eyed and gazing with a look both loving and fiery, that one surely with clustering locks, just now winding his cheek with the blond down of youth.
cf. cap. 12: βλέμμα γὰρ οὕτω λαμπρὸν καὶ εὐσχήμων ὄψις ἅμα καὶ ἐπέραστος εὐγενείας ἔμφασιν παρίστησιν.
For such a bright and well-ordered glance, loving yet noble, reveals high birth.

The shrubs and plants mentioned here are indeed the common ones in this area. Of the Tretos, see Pouqueville p. 148: the Tretos in which the river flows and the waters from the Rîto spring, amidst a thick thicket of myrtles, oleanders, and shrubs.
The holly, Ilex aquifolia L., Greek πρῖνος ἀγρία, Roman, aquifolium, is likewise frequent in this area: Expéd. de Morée t. III, p. 35: une campagne couverte de petits buissons et de houx,
a countryside covered with small bushes and holly between Corinth and Nemea. The strawberry tree, Arbutus unedo, is native to all of Greece. The yellow sage, Salvia pomifera, Greek σφάκος, now el, grows plentifully in the area. Dodwell p. 298: this plant is common in the rocky places in Greece.
[Nevertheless, the oleander had to be removed from the text because, according to V. Hehn Culturpflanzen und Hausthiere 2. Aufl. 1874, S. 358, it only migrated to Greece in the period between Theophrastus and the end of the Roman Republic.]

Dass die griechische Humanität den Reisenden gestattete, im Vorübergehen von den Früchten am Wege zu essen, daran darf man wohl nicht zweifeln. Vgl. das Epigramm der
Anthol. Pal. IX, 249:
εὐπέταλον γλαυκὰν ἀναδενδράδα τάνδε παρ᾽ ἄκραις
ἱδρυνϑεὶς λοφιαῖς Πὰν δ᾽ ἐπισκοπέω·
εἰ δέ σε πορφύροντος ἔχει πόϑος, ὦ παροδῖτα,
βότρυος, οὐ φϑονέω γαστρὶ χαριζομένῳ·
ἣν δὲ χερὶ ψαύσῃς κλοπίῃ μόνον, αὐτίκα δέξῃ
ὀζαλέην βάχτρου τήνδε καρηβαρίην.
Having established myself on this soft-leaved gray-green oak tree on the hilltop edges, I, Pan, keep watch. If you have a craving, traveler, for the dark cluster, I do not begrudge the belly its delight. But if you touch it with thieving hand only, at once you will receive a weighty blow of my staff on your head.
Plato, der die speciellsten Vorschriften giebt, in wie weit auch ein Einheimischer sich so etwas erlauben dürfe, sagt

VIII, p. 845: ἐὰν δέ ξένος ἐπιδημήσας ὀπώρας ἐπιϑυμῇ φαγεῖν διαπορευόμενος τὰς ὁδούς, τῆς μὲν γενναίας (ὀπώρας, γενναίων σταφυλῶν ἣ σύκων) ἁπτέσϑω, ἐὰν βούληται, μεθ’ ἑνὸς ἀκολούϑου, χωρὶς τιμῆς, ξένια δεχόμενος· τῆς δὲ ἀγροίκου λεγομένης καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ὁ νόμος εἰργέτω μὴ κοινωνεῖν ἡμῖν τοὺς ξένους.
If a stranger visiting during the fruit season desires to eat some as he travels the roads, let him partake, if he wishes, of the choice fruits (of grapes or figs) without payment, accepting hospitality, together with one attendant. But the law should forbid strangers from sharing with us the common and such sorts of fruits.
Was er unter ὀπώρα γενναία und ὀπώρα ἀγροῖκος versteht, das lehren die folgenden Worte, wo er verordnet, wenn ein Fremder unwissentlich gegen dieses Gesetz gehandelt habe,

Anthol. Pal. IX, 249:
εὐπέταλον γλαυκὰν ἀναδενδράδα τάνδε παρ᾽ ἄκραις
ἱδρυνϑεὶς λοφιαῖς Πὰν δ᾽ ἐπισκοπέω·

βότρυος, οὐ φϑονέω γαστρὶ χαριζομένῳ·

Having established myself on this soft-leaved gray-green oak tree on the hilltop edges, I, Pan, keep watch. If you have a craving, traveler, for the dark cluster, I do not begrudge the belly its delight. Plato, who provides the most specific regulations about to what extent even a local might allow themselves such a thing, says:
Leg. VIII, p. 845: ἐὰν δέ ξένος ἐπιδημήσας ὀπώρας ἐπιϑυμῇ φαγεῖν διαπορευόμενος τὰς ὁδούς, τῆς μὲν γενναίας (ὀπώρας, γενναίων σταφυλῶν ἣ σύκων) ἁπτέσϑω, ἐὰν βούληται, μεθ’ ἑνὸς ἀκολούϑου, χωρὶς τιμῆς, ξένια δεχόμενος· τῆς δὲ ἀγροίκου λεγομένης καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ὁ νόμος εἰργέτω μὴ κοινωνεῖν ἡμῖν τοὺς ξένους.
If a stranger visiting during the fruit season desires to eat some as he travels the roads, let him partake, if he wishes, of the choice fruits (of grapes or figs) without payment, accepting hospitality, together with one attendant. But the law should forbid strangers from sharing with us the common and such sorts of fruits.

Leg. VIII, p. 845: τὸν μὲν δοῦλον πληγαῖς κολάζειν, τὸν δὲ ἐλεύϑερον ἀποπέμπειν, νουϑετήσαντα καὶ διδάξαντα τῆς ἄλλης ὀπώρας ἅπτεσϑαι τῆς εἰς ἀπόϑεσιν ὀσταφίδος οἴνου τε καὶ ξηρῶν σύκων ἀνεπιτηδείου κεκτῆσϑαι.
The slave should be beaten as punishment, but the free man should be sent away after admonishing him and teaching that he should partake of the other harvest destined for drying into raisins and inferior figs.

Die Sucht, einen langen Stammbaum berühmter Vorfahren aufzustellen und wo möglich die unmittelbare Abstammung seines Geschlechts von einem Gotte oder Heros nachweisen zu wollen, darf bei den Griechen nicht Wunder nehmen. Sie wird immer da am entschiedensten hervortreten, wo man sich dem auf die Gottheit zurückzuführenden Ursprunge des Menschengeschlechts am nächsten glaubt. Ueberdies gaben den späteren Geschlechtern die Genealogien berühmter Namen der frühesten Zeit ein treffliches Mittel in die Hände, bis auf den Urquell des Daseins zurückzugehen, und wo die Grenze zwischen Einheimischen und Fremden so scharf gezogen war, oder einzelne Geschlechter uralte Vorrechte genossen, da konnte Ahnenstolz keine auffallende Erscheinung sein, wenn er auch von dem Verständigen als thöricht bemitleidet und oft genug verspottet wurde. So z. B. The desire to establish a long family tree of famous ancestors and, if possible, to prove the direct descent of their family from a god or hero, should not surprise us in the Greeks. It will always appear most clearly where one believes that the origin of the human race, which can be traced back to the gods, is closest.
Furthermore, the genealogies of famous names from the earliest times gave later generations a valuable means of going back to the source of existence, and where the boundary between natives and foreigners was so clearly drawn, or where individual families enjoyed ancient privileges, ancestral pride could not be a striking phenomenon, even if it was often pitied as foolish by the discerning and often enough mocked. For example, Aristoph. Nub. 48: ἔγημα Μεγακλέους τοῦ Μεγακλέους ἀδελφιδῆν,
I married the niece of Megacles the son of Megacles.
wo die Worte wohl eine Anspielung auf Alkibiades enthalten,
der sein Geschlecht von väterlicher Seite von Aias ableitete, dessen Mutter aber Deinomache, die Tochter des Megakles, zu den Alkmäoniden gehörte. Des Redners Andokides Stammbaum reichte nach Hellanikos bis zu Odysseus und demnach auch bis zu Hermes und Zeus, Plut. Alcib. 21. X Orat. p. 884 C,
[der des Historikers Hekatäos nach Herod. II, 143 im sechzehnten Gliede ebenfalls bis zu einem Gott] hinauf. S. Wachsmuth B. I, S. 383. 555. Die belehrendste Stelle über die doppelte Ansicht von dem Werthe solches Erbadels findet sich bei Plato Theaetetus , dessen Urtheil um so grösseren Werth hat, als Plato selbst von väterlicher wie von mütterlicher Seite aus altem edlem Geschlechte abstammte :
Here the words are probably an allusion to Alkibiades,
who traced his lineage from his father's side to Aias,
while his mother, Deinomache, the daughter of Megakles, belonged to the Alcmaeonids. The orator Andokides' family tree, according to Hellanicus, goes back to Odysseus and thus also to Hermes and Zeus, Plutarch, Alkibiades 21. X Orat. p. 884 C,
[the family tree of the historian Hekataios, according to Herodotus II, 143, goes back to a god in the sixteenth generation] likewise. See Wachsmuth B. I, p. 383. 555. Plato Theaet. p. 175: τὰ δὲ δὴ γένη ὑμνούντων, ὡς γενναῖός τις ἑπτὰ πάππους πλουσίους ἔχων ἀποφῆναι, παντάπασιν ἀμβλὺ καὶ ἐπὶ σμικρὸν δρώντων ἡγεῖται (ὁ φιλόσοφος) τὸν ἔπαινον, ἀπὸ ἀπαιδευσίας οὐ δυναμένων εἰς τὸ πᾶν ἀεὶ βλέπειν οὐδὲ λογίζεσθαι, ὅτε πάππων καὶ προγόνων μυριάδες ἑκάστῳ γεγόνασιν ἀναρίϑμητοι, ἐν αἷς πλούσιοι καὶ πτωχοἰ, καὶ βασιλεῖς καὶ δοῦλοι, βάρβαροί τε καὶ Ἕλληνες πολλάκις μυρίοι γεγόνασιν ὁτῳοῦν· ἀλλ᾽ ἐπὶ πέντε καὶ εἴκοσι καταλόγῳ npoγόνων σεμνυνομένων καὶ ἀναφερόντων εἰς Ἠρακλέα τὸν Ἀμφιτρύωvos ἄτοπα αὐτῷ καταφαίνεται τῆς σμικρολογίας.
And when people extol lineages, as though one were proving himself noble by displaying seven wealthy ancestors, the philosopher regards their praise as utterly dull-witted and shortsighted, since out of lack of education they cannot look to the whole and recognize that each person has had myriads upon myriads of ancestors, among whom have been countless times ten thousand rich and poor, kings and slaves, barbarians and Greeks - anyone you please. But when people pride themselves on a pedigree of twenty-five ancestors and trace their lineage back to Heracles son of Amphitryon, their petty preciseness seems absurd to him.
[Vgl. Menander bei Stob. Serm. LXXXVII, 4, Lobeck Aglaoph. p. 764, K. Keil Zwei Inschr. aus Sparta und Gythion, 8.26. Böckh Corp. Inscr. I, 2, p. 421, n. 2568. Auch in der römischen Zeit blieb den Griechen diese Eitelkeit. Der berühmte Herodes Atticus leitete sein Geschlecht bis auf die Aeakiden zurück: Philostr. vitt. sophist. II. 1 und von dem prahlenden Eukleides sagt Martial Epigr. V, 35: longumque pulchra stemma repetit a Leda.]

But if he is fond of living in Aenos, in doing this he does not deprive himself of any service to the state, nor has he become a citizen of any other state, as I see some men do - some going to live on the continent and dwelling among your enemies and prosecuting legal disputes with you arising from commercial agreements.

But if he is fond of living in Aenos, in doing this he does not deprive himself of any service to the state, nor has he become a citizen of any other state, as I see some men do - some going to live on the continent and dwelling among your enemies and prosecuting legal disputes with you arising from commercial agreements.
Cf. Lys.in Philon. 8. 9. This was not forbidden to anyone, as Plato explicitly states in Crito p.51. However, the state naturally did not like it, and in this sense, it could always be a cause for reproach. In Sparta, there was a death penalty for μετοικισμός: Plut. Agid. 11.

Der Grundsatz: ubi bene, ibi patria, ist nicht neu. Wie er das Motiv zu den Vögeln des Aristophanes ist, so lässt derselbe Dichter Plut. 1151 ihn unumwunden durch Hermes aussprechen:
Aristoph. Plut. 1151
πατρὶς γάρ ἐστι πᾶσ᾽, ἵν᾽ ἂν πράττῃ τις εὖ.
For everything is a fatherland wherever one can live well.
[Der römische Dichter Pacuvius gab diesen Satz in seinem Teucer so wieder:
Pacuvius, Teucer patria est, ubicunque est bene
One's homeland is wherever one is well
, vgl. Cic. Tusc. V, 37 mit der Anm. von Davis. Dass die kosmopolitisch gesinnten Sophisten demselben Grundsatze huldigten [Plat. Tim. p. kann nicht befremden.]

The principle: ubi bene, ibi patria where it is well, there is my fatherland. is not new. Just as it is the motif for Aristophanes' 'The Birds', the same poet unreservedly has Hermes express it in:
Aristoph. Plut. 1151
πατρὶς γάρ ἐστι πᾶσ᾽, ἵν᾽ ἂν πράττῃ τις εὖ.
For everything is a homeland wherever one can live well.
[The Roman poet Pacuvius repeated this sentence in his Teucer in this way:
Pacuvius, Teucer patria est, ubicunque est bene
One's homeland is wherever one is well
. Compare Cicero, Tusculan Disputations, V, 37 with the note of Davis. It is not surprising that the cosmopolitan-minded Sophists adhered to the same principle (Plato, Timaeus, p. 19).]

The Greek, it seems, looked forward to the first appearance of birds, whose return heralds the spring, even more eagerly than we do. Hence the proverbial cry of joy ὥρα νέα, χελιδών .
Aristoph. Equit. 419: Σκέφψασϑε, παῖδες, οὐχ ὁρᾶϑ'; ὥρα νέα, χελιδών.
look, children, don't you see? A new season -- the swallow.
and the comic lament of Mnesilochos
Thesmoph. 1: ὦ Ζεῦ, χελιδὼν ἆρα πότε φανήσεται;
O Zeus, when will the swallow appear?
[Especially relevant here is the Rhodian lullaby
Athen. VII, 60 p. 360:
ἦλθ᾽, ἦλϑε χελιδών,
καλὰς ὥρας ἄγουσα,
καλοὺς ἐνιαυτούς,
ἐπὶ γαστέρα λευκά,
ἐπὶ νῶτα μέλαινα. κ. τ. λ.
The swallow has come, the swallow has come,
bringing the fair seasons,
bringing the good years,
upon her white belly,
upon her black back, etc.
Even today, children in Greece sing a similar song on March 1st, by turning a wooden swallow on a cylinder: G. Wolff im Philol. Anz. 1872, IV, 8. 144. Vase paintings: Monum. ined. dell’ Instit. arch. II, 24 mit Panofka in den Annali 1835, t. VII, p. 233—242.] — Even the proverb "One swallow does not make a summer" is literally the same in Greek. Aristot. Ethic. Nicom. I, 6, p. 1098:
μία γὰρ χελιδὼν ἔαρ οὐ ποιεῖ.
A single swallow does not make it spring.
The kite, ἴκτινος, which appears even earlier, was greeted with joy in the same way..
Aristoph. Av. 712:
ἴκτινος δ᾽ αὖ μετὰ ταῦτα φανεὶς ἑτέραν ὥραν ἀποφαίνει,
ἡνίκα πεκτεῖν ὥρα προβάτων πόκον ἠρινόν· εἶτα χελιδών,
ὅτε χρὴ χλαῖναν πωλεῖν ἤδη καὶ ληδάριόν τι πρίασϑαι.
And then the kite appears, announcing another season,
when it is time to pluck the spring fleece of the sheep; then the swallow,
when one must now sell one's cloak and buy a light coat.
The exuberant joy over their arrival is expressed by the idiom v. 500 προκυλίνδεσθαι τοῖς ἰκτίνοις
to tumble forward at the hoopoes
, on which
the Scholiast remarks: Scholiast ἔαρος ἀρχομένου ἴκτινος φαίνεται εἰς τὴν Ἑλλάδα, ἐφ᾽ ᾧ ἡδόμενοι κυλίνδονται.
At the beginning of spring the hoopoe appears in Greece, at which they [?] roll about in delight.

One could see at the doors freeborn women, frightened and crouching, asking if their loved ones were alive - some for a husband, some for a father, some for brothers - a sight unworthy of them and of the city. Of the men, one could see those exhausted in body and advanced in years, exempt by law from military service, making their way with staffs throughout the whole city, wrapped in double cloaks. And though many terrible things were happening in the city and all the citizens had suffered greatly, one would have felt the most pain and wept for the misfortunes of the city, when one saw the people voting to free the slaves, make foreigners citizens, and restore civil rights to the disenfranchised.

ὁρᾶν δ᾽ ἦν ἐπὶ μὲν τῶν ϑυρῶν γυναῖκας ἐλευϑέρας, περιφόβους, κατεπτηκυίας καὶ πυνϑανομένας, εἰ ζῶσι, τὰς μὲν ὑπὲρ ἀνδρός, τὰς δ' ὑπὲρ πατρός, τὰς δ᾽ ὑπὲρ ἀδελφῶν, ἀναξίως αὑτῶν καὶ τῆς πόλεως ὁρωμένας. τῶν δὲ ἀνδρῶν τοὺς τοῖς σώμασιν ἀπειρηκότας καὶ τὰς ἡλικίας πρεσβυτέρους καὶ ὑπὸ τῶν νόμων τοῦ στρατεύεσθαι ἀφειμένους ἰδεῖν ἦν καθ᾽ ὅλην τὴν πόλιν ἐπὶ γήρως ὁδῷ περιφϑειρομένους, διπλᾶ τὰ ἱμάτια ἐμπεπορπημένους. πολλῶν δὲ καὶ δεινῶν κατὰ τήν πόλιν γιγνομένων καὶ πάντων τῶν πολιτῶν τὰ μέγιστα ἠτυκηκότων, μάλιστ᾽ ἄν τις ἤλγησε καὶ ἐδάκρυεν ἐπὶ ταῖς τῆς πόλεως συμφοραῖς, ἡνίχ᾽ ὁρᾶν ἦν τὸν δῆμον φηφισάμενον τοὺς μὲν δούλους ἐλευϑέρους, τοὺς δὲ ξένους Ἀθηναίους, τοὺς δ᾽ ἀτίμους ἐπιτίμους.

One could see at the doors freeborn women, frightened and crouching, asking if their loved ones were alive - some for a husband, some for a father, some for brothers - a sight unworthy of them and of the city. Of the men, one could see those exhausted in body and advanced in years, exempt by law from military service, making their way with staffs throughout the whole city, wrapped in double cloaks. And though many terrible things were happening in the city and all the citizens had suffered greatly, one would have felt the most pain and wept for the misfortunes of the city, when one saw the people voting to free the slaves, make foreigners citizens, and restore civil rights to the disenfranchised.

note.p:
Lykurg 39: ἡνίκα ἡ μὲν ἧττα καὶ τὸ γεγονὸς πάϑος προςηγγέλλετο.
When the defeat and the suffered misfortune were being announced.
Wem? fehlt in den Hdschr.; vergleicht man aber den Geschäftsgang bei einem ähnlichen Ereignisse, der Einnahme von Elateia (
Demosth. de cor. 169: ἑσπέρα γὰρ ἦν, ἧκε δ᾽ ἀγγέλλων τις ὧς τοὺς πρυτάνεις, ὡς Ἐλάτεια κατείληπται ---· τῇ δ' ὑστεραίᾳ ἅμα τῇ ἡμέρᾳ οἱ μὲν πρυτάνεις τὴν βουλὴν ἐκάλουν εἰς τὸ βουλευτήριον, ὑμεῖς δ᾽ εἰς τὴν ἐκκλησίαν ἐπορεύεσϑε —· καὶ μετὰ ταῦτα ὡς εἰςῆλθεν ἣ βουλὴ καὶ ἀπήγγειλαν τὰ προςηγγελμένα ἑαυτοῖς καὶ τὸν ἥκοντα παρήγαγον κ. τ. λ.
For it was evening when a messenger came to the prytanes with news that Elatea had been seized. On the next day at dawn, the prytanes summoned the council to the council house while you made your way to the assembly. After this, when the council entered and reported to themselves the news that had been announced and brought forward the messenger, etc.
), so wird es wahrscheinlich, dass auch die Nachricht von der Niederlage zuerst in das Prytaneion gelangt war und von da aus dem Volke bekannt gemacht wurde.

Lykurg 39: ἡνίκα ἡ μὲν ἧττα καὶ τὸ γεγονὸς πάϑος προςηγγέλλετο.
When the defeat and the suffered misfortune were being announced.
Whom? is missing in the manuscripts; however, if we compare the course of events in a similar case, the capture of Elateia. (Demosth. de cor. 169: ἑσπέρα γὰρ ἦν, ἧκε δ᾽ ἀγγέλλων τις ὧς τοὺς πρυτάνεις, ὡς Ἐλάτεια κατείληπται ---· τῇ δ' ὑστεραίᾳ ἅμα τῇ ἡμέρᾳ οἱ μὲν πρυτάνεις τὴν βουλὴν ἐκάλουν εἰς τὸ βουλευτήριον, ὑμεῖς δ᾽ εἰς τὴν ἐκκλησίαν ἐπορεύεσϑε —· καὶ μετὰ ταῦτα ὡς εἰςῆλθεν ἣ βουλὴ καὶ ἀπήγγειλαν τὰ προςηγγελμένα ἑαυτοῖς καὶ τὸν ἥκοντα παρήγαγον κ. τ. λ.
For it was evening when a messenger came to the prytanes with news that Elatea had been seized. On the next day at dawn, the prytanes summoned the council to the council house while you made your way to the assembly. After this, when the council entered and reported to themselves the news that had been announced and brought forward the messenger, etc.
). Thus, it is likely that the news of the defeat also first reached the Prytaneion and was announced to the people from there.

Die Weise, in der solche Geschäfte betrieben wurden, ersieht man am besten aus den Reden des Demosthenes gegen Lakritos und Dionysodoros. S. Böckh Staatsh. d. Ath. Β.1, 8. 185 ff. [und Büchsenschütz Besitz und Erwerb im griech. Alterthum. Halle 1869. S. 487.]

The best way to understand how these businesses were conducted is by examining the speeches of Demosthenes against Lakritos and Dionysodoros. See Böckh, Staatsh. d. Ath. Β.1, 8. 185 ff. [and Büchsenschütz Besitz und Erwerb im griech. Alterthum. Halle 1869. p. 487.]
Nämlich gegen das Gesetz, nach welchem kein Athener Geld zu Getraidehandel nach fremden Hüfen leihen durfte. Demosth. in Laer. 8.50. S. Bóckh 8.79ff. [u. Büchsenschütza. a. O. 8. 547.]
Specifically, against the law that no Athenian was allowed to lend money for grain trade to foreign ports. Demosth. in Laer. 8.50. See Böckh 8.79ff. [and Büchsenschütza. a. O. 8. 547.]
Lykurg. in Leocr. 16.
Lykurg. in Leocr. 16.
Er wurde auf Lykurgs Anklage zum Tode verurtheilt. S. Diodor. Sic. XVI. 88, wo eine schöne Stelle aus Lykurgs Rede aufbewahrt ist.
He was sentenced to death on the accusation of Lykurgus. See Diodor. Sic. XVI. 88, where a fine passage fro Lycurgus' speech is preserved.

Auch hier ist mit wenigen Abänderungen die Erzählung von der Flucht des Leokrates zu Grunde gelegt.
Lycurg. 17: συσκευασάμενος ἃ εἶχε χρήματα μετὰ τῶν οἰκετῶν ἐπὶ τὸν λέμβον κατεκόμισε, τῆς νεὼς ἤδη περὶ τὴν ἀκτὴν ἐξορμώσης· καὶ περὶ δείλην ὀψίαν αὐτὸς μετὰ τῆς ἑταίρας Εἰρηνίδος κατὰ μέσην τὴν ἀκτὴν διὰ τῆς Πυλίδος ἐξελθὼν πρὸς τὴν ναῦν προςέπλευσε καὶ ᾤχετο φεύγων.
Having packed up the money he had along with his servants, he brought it down to the boat, as the ship was already putting out from the shore. And in the late afternoon, around sunset, he himself with his companion the courtesan Eirenides came out through the Pylid gateway midway along the shore and sailed out to the ship and fled away.
Vgl. 55, wo ein Bild der Abreise aus dem Hafen (Lycurg. 55: ἀπὸ πάντων τῶν φίλων ὁρώμενοι καὶ ἀποστελλόμενοι,
Seen off by all his friends, .
vgl. Antiph. de venef. S. 16. Lucian. Amor. 6) dagegen gehalten wird.

Here, too, the story of the flight of Leocrates is the basis, with a few changes.
Lycurg. 17: συσκευασάμενος ἃ εἶχε χρήματα μετὰ τῶν οἰκετῶν ἐπὶ τὸν λέμβον κατεκόμισε, τῆς νεὼς ἤδη περὶ τὴν ἀκτὴν ἐξορμώσης· καὶ περὶ δείλην ὀψίαν αὐτὸς μετὰ τῆς ἑταίρας Εἰρηνίδος κατὰ μέσην τὴν ἀκτὴν διὰ τῆς Πυλίδος ἐξελθὼν πρὸς τὴν ναῦν προςέπλευσε καὶ ᾤχετο φεύγων.
Having packed up the money he had along with his servants, he brought it down to the boat, as the ship was already putting out from the shore. And in the late afternoon, around sunset, he himself with his companion the courtesan Eirenides came out through the Pylid gateway midway along the shore and sailed out to the ship and fled away.
Cf. 55, where an image of the departure from the harbor (Lycurg. 55: ἀπὸ πάντων τῶν φίλων ὁρώμενοι καὶ ἀποστελλόμενοι,
Seen off by all his friends, .
cf. Antiph. de venef. p. 16. Lucian. Amor. 6) by contrast is preserved.

Nach Isocr. Aegin. 22: ὅτι τὸ χωρίον (Τροιζῆνα) ἐπυνθάνετο νοσῶδες εἶναι.
because he had heard that the place (Troezen) was unhealthy
[Besonders das Trinkwasser in Trözen war verrufen (Athen. II, 16) und erzeugte nach Vitruv. VIII. 3 und Plin. N. H. XXXI, 2, 11. das Podagra. Curtius Peloponn. B. II, S. 438 schreibt die heutige Ungesundheit des dortigen Klimas der niedrigen Küste, Bursian Geogr. II, 8. 83 den Ausdünstungen der baumartigen Wolfsmilch (Euphorbia dendroides) zu.]

According to Isocr. Aegin. 22: ὅτι τὸ χωρίον (Τροιζῆνα) ἐπυνθάνετο νοσῶδες εἶναι.
because he had heard that the place (Troezen) was unhealthy
[Especially the drinking water in Troezen was infamous (Athen. II, 16) and, according to Vitruvius VIII. 3 and Pliny N. H. XXXI, 2, 11, caused gout. Curtius Peloponn. B. II, p. 438 attributes the current unhealthiness of the climate there to the low coast, Bursian Geogr. II, 8. 83 to the emanations of the tree-like milkweed (Euphorbia dendroides).]

Wie Aelian. Var. Hist. XII, 52 erzählt, verglich Isokrates Athen mit einer Hetäre, an deren Reizen man wohl flüchtiges Gefallen finde, die aber niemand zur Frau haben möge:
Aelian. Var. Hist. XII, 52 καὶ οὖν καὶ τὴν Ἀϑηναίων πόλιν ἐνεπιδημῆσαι μὲν εἶναι ἡδίστην καὶ κατά γε τοῦτο πασῶν τῶν κατὰ τὴν Ἑλλάδα διαφέρειν, ἐνοικῆσαι δὲ ἀσφαλῇ μηκέτι εἶναι: und ähnlich soll Aristoteles, um sein Urtheil über Athen befragt (τίς ἐστιν ἡ τῶν Ἀϑηναίων πόλις), geantwortet haben: παγκάλη, ἀλλ᾽ ἐν αὐτῇ ὄγχνη ἐπ᾽ ὄγχνῃ γηράσκει, σῦκον δ᾽ ἐπὶ σύκῳ· τοὺς συκοφάντας λέγων,
And so they say that the city of the Athenians is most pleasant to visit and in this respect surpasses all cities in Greece, but is no longer safe to dwell in. And similarly when Aristotle was asked about his opinion of Athens (What is the city of the Athenians like?), he is said to have answered:
"Very beautiful, but in it pear is grafted on pear, fig on fig; I speak of the slanderers."
setzt Aelian. V. Hist. III, 36 hinzu; vgl. K. F. Hermann ad Lucian. Hist. conscr. p. 249 - und mehr unten Sc. IV, Anm. 13.

As Aelian tells us in Varia Historia XII, 52, Isocrates compared Athens to a courtesan, whose charms might be enjoyed briefly, but whom no one would want as a wife.:
Aelian. Var. Hist. XII, 52 καὶ οὖν καὶ τὴν Ἀϑηναίων πόλιν ἐνεπιδημῆσαι μὲν εἶναι ἡδίστην καὶ κατά γε τοῦτο πασῶν τῶν κατὰ τὴν Ἑλλάδα διαφέρειν, ἐνοικῆσαι δὲ ἀσφαλῇ μηκέτι εἶναι: und ähnlich soll Aristoteles, um sein Urtheil über Athen befragt (τίς ἐστιν ἡ τῶν Ἀϑηναίων πόλις), geantwortet haben: παγκάλη, ἀλλ᾽ ἐν αὐτῇ ὄγχνη ἐπ᾽ ὄγχνῃ γηράσκει, σῦκον δ᾽ ἐπὶ σύκῳ· τοὺς συκοφάντας λέγων,
And so they say that the city of the Athenians is most pleasant to visit and in this respect surpasses all cities in Greece, but is no longer safe to dwell in. And similarly when Aristotle was asked about his opinion of Athens (What is the city of the Athenians like?), he is said to have answered:
"Very beautiful, but in it
pear is grafted on pear, fig on fig; I speak of the slanderers,"
Aelian adds in V. Hist. III, 36.; cf. K. F. Hermann ib Lucian. Hist. conscr. p. 249 - and more in Sc. IV, note. 13.

Philo t. II, p. 467 Mangey: ὅπερ ἐν ὀφϑαλμῷ κόρη ἣ ἐν ψυχῇ λογισμός, τοῦτ᾽ ἐν Ἑλλάδι Ἀϑῆναι,
Just as the pupil is in the eye, and reason/logic is in the soul, so is Athens in Greece
vgl.
Dicaearch. p. 141 Fuhr: ὅσον αἱ λοιπαὶ πόλεις πρός τε ἡδονὴν καὶ βίου διόρϑωσιν τῶν ἀγρῶν διαφέρουσι, τοσοῦτον τῶν λοιπῶν πόλεων ἡ τῶν Ἀϑηναίων παραλλάττει,
As much as the other cities differ in terms of pleasure and way of life from the countryside, by that much the city of the Athenians differs from the other cities.
eine Huldigung, welche Athen gebührt, man mag
auf den äusseren Glanz Rücksicht nehmen, den der Verein aller Künste in hober Vollkommenheit der Stadt verliehen hatte, oder auf Bildung und feine Sitte, oder den lebhaften Verkehr, der es gleichsam zum Marktplatze der Welt machte. Auf den ersten Vorzug mag es zu beziehen sein, wenn bei Athen. I, 36 im Vergleiche anderer Städte gesagt wird:
Athen. I, 36 Ἀλεξανδρέων μὲν τὴν χρυσῆν, Ἀντιοχέων δὲ τὴν καλήν, Νικομηδέων δὲ τὴν περικαλλῆ, προσέτι δὲ
τὴν λαμπροτάτην πόλεων πασῶν, ὁπόσας ὁ Ζεὺς ἀναφαίνει,
τὰς Ἀθήνας λέγω:
Of the Alexandrians the golden city, of the Antiocheans the fair city, of the Nicomedians the very beautiful city, and in addition
"the most brilliant of all cities, as many as Zeus brings to light,"
I speak of Athens.
The passage refers poetically to various famous cities - Alexandria, Antioch, Nicomedia - before quoting a line from the Iliad about Athens being the most brilliant city.
in Bezug auf den letzten sagt noch
Charit. I, 11: ὥσπερ γὰρ ἐν ἀγορᾷ τοὺς ἄνδρας, οὕτως ἐν Ἀϑήναις τὰς πόλεις ἔστιν ἰδεῖν.
For just as in the marketplace one can see the men, so in Athens one can see the cities.
Alciphr. II, 8: (ὄψομαι) ὅλην ἐν ταῖς Ἀϑήναις τὴν Ἑλλάδα, ὅλην τὴν Ἰωνίαν, τὰς Κυκλάδας πάσας:
(I will see) all Greece in Athens, all Ionia, all the Cyclades.
[Creuzer Oratio de civitate Athenarum omnis humanitatis parente, Frankf. a. M. 1826, 8, namentlich p. 51 ff. Bergk Griech. Literatur in Hall. Encyklop. LXXXI, S. 286.] Aber mehr als auf diesen äusseren Glanz durfte Athen darauf stolz sein, vor allen anderen Städten sich einen Tempel der Musen, eine ächte Pflegerin für Wissenschaft und Kunst, eine Schule für ganz Griechenland, ja κοινὸν παιδευτήριον πᾶσιν ἀνϑρώποις
the common school for all human beings.
(Diodor. Sic. XIII, 27)
nennen zu dürfen; und dieses Bewusstsein spricht sich nicht nur in der bekannten Leichenrede des Perikles bei Thucyd. II, 41, sondern auch in zahlreichen anderen Stellen seiner Redner und Dichter aus, worunter besonders Isokrates den Mund sehr voll zu nehmen pflegt; vgl. de bigis S. 27, de permut. δ. 299, and am stolzesten Paneg. 50: τοσοῦτον ἀπολέλοιπεν ἡ πόλις ἡμῶν περὶ τὸ φρονεῖν καὶ λέγειν τοὺς ἄλλους ἀνθρώπους, ὥσϑ' οἱ ταύτης μαϑηταὶ τῶν ἄλλων διδάσκαλοι γεγόνασι, καὶ τὸ τῶν Ἑλλήνων ὄνομα πεποίηκε μηκέτι τοῦ γένους ἀλλὰ τῆς διανοίας δοκεὶν εἶναι, καὶ μᾶλλον Ἕλληνας καλεῖσϑαι τοὺς τῆς παιδεύσεως τῆς ἡμετέρας ἢ τοὺς τῆς κοινῆς φύσεως μετέχοντας.
Our city has left behind for all mankind a common school of thought and speech, so that her disciples have become the teachers of others. And she has made the title of Greek indicate culture rather than race, and men are called Greeks because they share in our education rather than in our common nature.
[Auch Plato nannte ja Athen Plato Protag. p. 337 αὐτὸ τὸ πρυτανεῖον τῆς σοφίας
The very town hall of wisdom
und sagte ebendaselbst Plato Protag. p. 319: ἐγὼ γὰρ Ἀθηναίους ὥσπερ καὶ οἱ ἄλλοι Ἕλληνες φημὶ σοφοὺς εἶναι
For I, just like the other Greeks, say that the Athenians are wise.
und Herodotus bezeugt den Athenern als Ausländer: Herodot. I, 60 ἐν Ἀθηναίοισι τοῖσι πρώτοισι λεγομένοισι εἶναι Ἑλλήνων σοφίην.
among the Athenians who are said to be the first of the Greeks in wisdom
Ja, am Ende des peloponnesischen Krieges soll das delphische Orakel die Stadt τὴν κοινὴν ἑστίαν τῆς Ἑλλάδος genannt haben: Athen. V, 12; Aelian. V. Hist. IV, 6. Vgl. Cic. ad fam. VI, 1, 6: urbs, in qua nata et alta est ratio et moderatio vitae,
The city, in which [one] is born and [where] there is a high standard and moderation of life.
Wenn K. F. Hermann zu 8. 30
des Charikles Becker deshalb getadelt hat, weil er solche Lobsprüche bloss als Schmeicheleien behandle, welche der Eitelkeit des Volkes von seinen Rednern und Demagogen dargebracht und wodurch ein Dünkel erzeugt worden sei, der leicht zur Verachtung Anderer führte, so kann man Becker in Bezug auf die Zeit, in welcher der Roman spielt, sicher nicht Unrecht geben. Gefehlt hat er eben — und dies sagen wir besonders auch in Bezug auf die zweite Hälfte dieser Anmerkung — darin, dass er den Unterschied der Perioden vor und nach Perikles zu wenig hervorgehoben hat. Von den Athenern der sittenstrengen, patriotischen Zeit konnte noch Plato rühmen:
Plato Legg. I. p. 642 C. τό δὲ ὑπὸ πολλῶν λεγόμενον, ὡς ὅσοι Ἀθηναίων εἰσὶν ἀγαϑοὶ διαφερόντως εἰσὶ τοιοῦτοι, δοκεῖ ἀληϑέστατα λέγεσϑαι· μόνοι γὰρ ἄνευ ἀνάγκης, αὐτοφυῶς, ϑείᾳ μοίρᾳ ἀληϑῶς καὶ οὔτι πλαστῶς εἰσιν ἀγαϑοί.
But what is said by many, that those Athenians who are good are outstandingly so, seems to me to be most true; for alone without compulsion, naturally, by divine fortune truly and not pretentiously they are good.
Vgl. Bernhardy Grundriss der griech. Literatur. Dritte Bearb. 1861. B. I. S. 436.] Ausserdem wurde dem Volke beständig wiederholt, wie grosse Thaten in früherer Zeit von Athen ausgegangen seien, welche Verdienste es um ganz Griechenland habe. Darin gleichen sich alle Lob- und Begräbnisereden, die in der Regel ganz denselben Gang nehmen und zunächst den ziemlich zweideutigen Ruhm hervorheben, dass die Athener die einzigen Autochthonen in Griechenland seien, ein Ruhm, auf den man sich in der That nicht wenig eingebildet zu haben und der auch nicht bloss von den Rednern als Effectphrase benutzt worden zu sein scheint. Mehr als alle schϑοn klingenden Tiraden sprechen dafür die ernsten Worte Lykurgs, wo es in Bezug auf den angeführten Beschluss nach der Schlacht bei Chäroneia: in Leocr. 41 τοὺς δούλους ἐλευϑέρους, τοὺς ξένους Ἀϑηναίους εἶναι, The slaves to be free, the foreigners to be Athenians -
heisst: in Leocr. 41 [ὁ δῆμος] ὃς πρότερον ἐπὶ τῷ αὐτόχϑων εἶναι καὶ ἐλεύϑερος ἐσεμνύνετο,
[the common people] who previously prided themselves on being earthborn and free,
und eben so ernst sagt von sich der Chor bei Aristoph. Vesp. 1076:
Ἀττικοὶ μόνοι δικαίως εὐγενεῖς αὐτόχϑονες.
Only the Attic people [are] rightly noble native born.
Der Begriff des αὐτόχϑων εἶναι to be born from the soil ist verschieden gefasst worden, und es ist nicht uninteressant aus einer Zusammenstellung sämmtlicher Hauptstellen zu seben, welchen Sinn man damit verband. Ursprünglieh wollte man nichts anderes damit sagen, als dass die Bewohner Attikas von jeher diese Landschaft bewohnt hätten, ohne weder irgendwo verdrängt worden noch selbst eingewandert zu sein. So mit einfach Thucyd. II, 36: τὴν χώραν ἀεὶ οἱ αὐτοὶ οἰκοῦντες,
Always inhabiting the same land,
und deutlicher noch Lesbonax Protrept. p. 22: οἱ μὲν ἄλλοι πάντες Ἕλληνες ἐκ τῆς σφετέρας αὐτῶν μεταστάντες οἰκοῦσιν ἕκαστοι αὐτῶν, ἐξελάσαντες ἑτέρους καὶ αὐτοὶ ἐξελαϑέντες ὑφ᾽ ἐτέρων, καὶ κατὰ τοῦτο δύο φέρεσϑε καυχήματα ἀρετῆς· οὔτε γὰρ ἐξηλάϑητε τῆς σφετέρας αὐτῶν ὑπὸ οὐδαμῶν ἀνθρώπων οὔτε ἐξελάσαντες ἑτέρους αὐτοὶ οἰκεῖτε.
While all other Greeks have moved from their own lands and dwell each in their places, having driven out others and themselves having been driven out by others, you have two grounds for boasting of valor: for you were driven out by no men from your own land nor after driving out others do you yourselves inhabit it.
Während aber hier die Frage über den ersten Ursprung ganz unberücksichtigt bleibt, mischt sich zu ihrer Lösung anderwärts die Vorstellung des γηγενεῖς εἶναι, d. h. Erdgeborene im eigentlichen Sinne zu sein, bei. So bei
Demosth. Epitaph. 4: οὐ γὰρ μόνον εἰς πατέρ᾽ αὐτοῖς καὶ τῶν ἄνω προγόνων καθ' ἄνδρα ἀνενεγκεῖν ἑκάστῳ τὴν φύσιν ἔστιν, ἀλλ᾽ εἰς ὅλην κοινῇ τὴν ὑπάρχουσαν πατρίδα, ἧς αὐτόχϑονες ὁμολογοῦνται εἶναι· μόνοι γὰρ πάντων ἀνθρώπων, ἐξ ἧσπερ ἔφυσαν, ταύτην ᾧκησαν καὶ τοῖς ἐξ αὐτῶν παρέδωκαν,
For it is possible to trace back for each man not only to his father and earlier ancestors the nature of each, but for the whole native land collectively, of which they are acknowledged to be native born; for alone of all men, from the very land from which they sprang, they inhabited this land and handed it down to their descendants.
und denselben Sinn haben auch die Worte bei Plato Menex. p. 287: τῆς δ᾽ εὐγενείας πρῶτον ὑπῆρξε τοῖσδε ἡ τῶν προγόνων γένεσις, οὐκ ἔπηλυς οὖσα οὐδὲ τοὺς ἐγκόνους τούτους ἀποφηναμένη μετοικοῦντας ἐν τῇ χώρᾳ ἄλλοϑεν σφῶν ἠχόντων, ἀλλ' αὐτόχϑονας καὶ τῷ ὄντι ἐν πατρίδι οἰκοῦντας καὶ ζῶντας, καὶ τρεφομένους oby ὑπὸ μητρυιᾶς ὡς ἄλλοι, ἀλλ ὁπὸ μητρὸς τῆς χώρας ἐν ἡ ᾧκουν.
For it was the genesis first of their ancestors that established the nobility of these men, not having come in from outside nor revealing that the descendants were immigrants in the land, having come from elsewhere, but being native born and truly dwelling in their fatherland and living and being nourished not by a stepmother land like others but by their mother country in which they dwelt.
Dazu kommt nun noch bei Anderen die ausdrückliche Verwahrung gegen den Gedanken, als könnte in Attika das reine hellenische Blut sich mit fremdem vermischt haben.

Furthermore, the people were continually reminded of the great deeds that had originated from Athens in earlier times and its merits for all of Greece. In this, all eulogies and funeral speeches are alike, which usually follow the same pattern and primarily emphasize the somewhat ambiguous fame that the Athenians are the only autochthonous in Greece — a pride that they seem to have genuinely taken to heart and that does not appear to have been used by the speakers merely as a phrase for effect. More than all the beautifully worded tirades, Lycurgus's earnest words seem to affirm this, especially concerning the decision made after the Battle of Chaeronea:: in Leocr. 41 ὁρᾶν ἦν τὸν δῆμον ψηφισάμενον τοὺς μὲν δούλους ἐλευθέρους, τοὺς δὲ ξένους Ἀθηναίους, τοὺς δʼ ἀτίμους ἐπιτίμους· ὃς πρότερον ἐπὶ τῷ αὐτόχθων εἶναι καὶ ἐλεύθερος ἐσεμνύνετο It was possible to see the common people [the dêmos] vote to make slaves free, foreigners Athenians, and the disenfranchised enfranchised. [the common people] who previously prided himself on being born from the soil and free.
Even so speaks the chorus at: Aristoph. Vesp. 1076:
Ἀττικοὶ μόνοι δικαίως εὐγενεῖς αὐτόχϑονες.
Only the Attic people [are] rightly noble born from the soil.
The idea of αὐτόχϑων εἶναι to be born from the soil has been interpreted in different ways. It is not uninteresting to see from a compilation of all the main passages what meaning was associated with it. Originally, one wanted to say nothing more with it than that the inhabitants of Attica had inhabited this landscape from time immemorial, without being displaced anywhere or having immigrated themselves. So simply: Thucyd. II, 36: τὴν χώραν ἀεὶ οἱ αὐτοὶ οἰκοῦντες,
Always inhabiting the same land,
and even more clearly: Lesbonax Protrept. p. 22: οἱ μὲν ἄλλοι πάντες Ἕλληνες ἐκ τῆς σφετέρας αὐτῶν μεταστάντες οἰκοῦσιν ἕκαστοι αὐτῶν, ἐξελάσαντες ἑτέρους καὶ αὐτοὶ ἐξελαϑέντες ὑφ᾽ ἐτέρων, καὶ κατὰ τοῦτο δύο φέρεσϑε καυχήματα ἀρετῆς· οὔτε γὰρ ἐξηλάϑητε τῆς σφετέρας αὐτῶν ὑπὸ οὐδαμῶν ἀνθρώπων οὔτε ἐξελάσαντες ἑτέρους αὐτοὶ οἰκεῖτε.
While all other Greeks have moved from their own lands and dwell each in their places, having driven out others and themselves having been driven out by others, you have two grounds for boasting of valor: for you were driven out by no men from your own land nor after driving out others do you yourselves inhabit it.
While, however, here the question about the first origin remains completely disregarded, the idea of γηγενεῖς εἶναι, i.e. to be born of the earth in the literal sense, plays a role in its solution elsewhere. Likewise with:
Demosth. Epitaph. 4: οὐ γὰρ μόνον εἰς πατέρ᾽ αὐτοῖς καὶ τῶν ἄνω προγόνων καθ' ἄνδρα ἀνενεγκεῖν ἑκάστῳ τὴν φύσιν ἔστιν, ἀλλ᾽ εἰς ὅλην κοινῇ τὴν ὑπάρχουσαν πατρίδα, ἧς αὐτόχϑονες ὁμολογοῦνται εἶναι· μόνοι γὰρ πάντων ἀνθρώπων, ἐξ ἧσπερ ἔφυσαν, ταύτην ᾧκησαν καὶ τοῖς ἐξ αὐτῶν παρέδωκαν,
For it is possible to trace back for each man not only to his father and earlier ancestors the nature of each, but for the whole native land collectively, of which they are acknowledged to be native born; for alone of all men, from the very land from which they sprang, they inhabited this land and handed it down to their descendants.
The same meaning is also found in the words of Plato: Plato Menex. p. 287: τῆς δ᾽ εὐγενείας πρῶτον ὑπῆρξε τοῖσδε ἡ τῶν προγόνων γένεσις, οὐκ ἔπηλυς οὖσα οὐδὲ τοὺς ἐγκόνους τούτους ἀποφηναμένη μετοικοῦντας ἐν τῇ χώρᾳ ἄλλοϑεν σφῶν ἠχόντων, ἀλλ' αὐτόχϑονας καὶ τῷ ὄντι ἐν πατρίδι οἰκοῦντας καὶ ζῶντας, καὶ τρεφομένους oby ὑπὸ μητρυιᾶς ὡς ἄλλοι, ἀλλ ὁπὸ μητρὸς τῆς χώρας ἐν ἡ ᾧκουν.
For it was the genesis first of their ancestors that established the nobility of these men, not having come in from outside nor revealing that the descendants were immigrants in the land, having come from elsewhere, but being native born and truly dwelling in their fatherland and living and being nourished not by a stepmother land like others but by their mother country in which they dwelt.
In addition, there is also the explicit reservation against the thought that the pure Hellenic blood could have mixed with foreign blood in Attica.
Isocr. Paneg. 24: ταύτην γὰρ οἰκοῦμεν οὐχ ἑτέρους ἐκβαλόντες οὐδ᾽ ἐρήμην καταλαβόντες οὐδ' ἐκ πολλῶν ἐθνῶν μιγάδες συλλεγέντες, ἀλλ᾽ οὕτω καλῶς καὶ γνησίως γεγόναμεν, ὥστ᾽ ἐξ ἧσπερ ἔφυμεν, ταύτην ἔχοντες ἅπαντα τὸν χρόνον διατελοῦμεν, αὐτόχϑονες ὄντες καὶ τῶν ὀνομάτων τοῖς αὑτοῖς, οἷσπερ τοὺς οἰκειοτάτους, τὴν πόλιν ἔχοντες προσειπεῖν.
For we inhabit this land not by driving out others nor by taking possession of it deserted nor, mingled from many peoples, gathered together, but so nobly and genuinely are we come to be that, from the very land from which we sprang, this we continue to possess through all time, being native born and calling our city by the very names as those most akin to us.
The Menexenus expresses this idea most decisively and rejects every thought of a mixing of the inhabitants of Attica with foreign colonists: Plato Menex. p. 245: οὕτω δή τοι τό γε τῆς πόλεως γενναῖον καὶ ἐλεύϑερον βέβαιόν τε καὶ ὕγιές ἐστι καὶ φύσει μισοβάρβαρον διὰ τὸ εἰλιχρεvos εἶναι Ἕλληνες καὶ ἀμιγεῖς βαρβάρων. οὐ γὰρ Πέλοπες οὐδὲ Κάδμοι οὐδὲ Αἴγυπτοί τε καὶ Δαναοὶ οὐδὶ ἄλλοι πολλοί, φύσει μὲν βάρβαροι ὄντες νόμῳ δὲ Ἕλληνες, συνοικοῦσιν ἡμῖν, ἀλλ᾽ αὐτοὶ “Ἕλληνες, οὐ μιξοβάρβαροι οἰκοῦμεν.
Thus indeed the noble spirit and freedom of the city remains secure and healthy and by nature hostile to barbarians, because it is purely Greek and unmixed with barbarians. For not Pelops nor Cadmus nor Egyptians and Danaus nor many others, barbarian by nature but Greek by law, dwell with us, but we ourselves, Greeks, not half-barbarians, inhabit the city.
It is easy to imagine that the high value that the Athenians placed on this [their autochthonous origin] also gave rise to mockery, and the joke of Antisthenes,
harshly juxtaposing these γηγενεῖς earth-born with snails and grasshoppers, is very biting.

And he himself, mocking the Athenians prizing themselves on being earthborn, used to say they were no more noble born than snails and locusts.

Je weniger ich daran denken durfte, aus der Reihe der Bilder, in welchen das griechische Privatleben sich darstellen soll, eine Schilderung des Hetärenlebens, dem griechische Leichtfertigkeit eine so eigenthümliche Farbe verliehen hatte und das so tief in das Leben, der jungen Leute besonders, eingriff, ganz auszulassen, desto schwieriger war es, für ein solches Bild ein Motiv zu wählen, das sich einigermassen mit Decenz behandeln liess. Es hätten aus den Schriften der Alten selbst sich sehr interessante Situationen der Art entnehmen lassen; allein wenn man auch ganz von der gemeineren Klasse solcher Geschöpfe absehen wollte, so würde demungeachtet eine Darstellung dieses wüsten Lebens und Treibens, die Schilderung des Tons, der im Umgange mit ihnen herrschte, wenn man anders wahr und treu darstellen wollte, für unser sittliches Gefühl gar sehr beleidigend sein. Je weniger der Grieche aus dergleichen Liebesverhältnissen ein Geheimniss machte, je milder die allgemeine Stimme darüber urtheilte, und je weniger man daher Ursache hatte, sich im Clairobscur verschämter Sentimentalität zu halten oder den Schleier der Heimlichkeit darüber zu ziehen, desto offener und unverhüllter tritt überall der wollüstige Zweck dieses Umgangs hervor, und es bieten die Symposien, an denen Hetären Theil nehmen, Scenen dar, zu deren Schilderung ich meine Feder nicht leihen möchte. — Ich habe daher einen der gewiss häufigen Fälle gewählt, wo das Gewerbe etwas weniger öffentlich getrieben wurde, und es schien mir nicht nöthig, zur Andeutung des allgemeinen Charakters solcher Häuser mich in das Detail verliebter Scenen einzulassen. Sollte aber jemand meinen, dass eben dadurch die Darstellung zu sehr in den Ton des Romans oder der Novelle verfallen sei, so muss ich zu meiner Rechtfertigung anführen, dass ich im Grunde sehr wenig hinzugethan habe und dass fast allen Zügen des Gemäldes, bis auf
Kleinigkeiten herab, klassische Stellen zu Grunde liegen. Hauptsächlich ist der Stoff aus mehreren Stellen der Rede gegen Neära und der des Lysias über den an Eratosthenes verübten Mord genommen; doch haben auch Lucians Toxaris, die Hetärengespräche, der Esel, oder Appulejus in den Metamorphosen, Heliodor, die Komiker u. a, Beiträge geliefert. Ich glaube nicht, dass man sagen könnte, durch diese Zusammensetzung einzelner Fragmente sei ein Bild entstanden, gas als Ganzes sich doch in der Wirklichkeit nicht finde. Im Gegentheile liegt allerdings ein Factum zu Grunde, der verdriessliche Handel des Epänetos, den (Pseudo-)Demosthenes in Neaer. S. 64 fg. also erzählt: Ἐπαίνετον γὰρ τὸν Ἄνδριον ἐραστὴν ὄντα Νεαίρας ταυτησὶ παλαιὸν xal πολλὰ ἀνηλωκότα εἰς αὐτὴν καὶ καταγόμενον παρὰ τούτοις, ὁπότε ἐπιδημήσειεν Ἀϑήναζε διὰ τὴν φιλίαν τῆς Νεαίρας, ἐπιβουλεύσας ὁ Στέφανος οὗτοσί, μεταπεμψάμενος εἰς ἀγρὸν ὡς ϑύων, λαμβάνει μοιχὸν ἐπὶ τῇ ϑυγατρὶ τῆς Νεαίρας ταυτησὶ καὶ εἰς φόβον καταστήσας πράττεται μνᾶς τριάκοντα· καὶ λαβὼν ἐγγυητὰς τούτων Ἡριστόμαχόν τε τὸν ϑεσμοϑετήσαντα καὶ Ναυσίφιλον τὸν Ναυσινίκου τοῦ ἄρξαντος υἱόν, ἀφέησιν ὡς ἀποδώσοντ᾽ αὐτῷ τὸ ἀργύριον. Mit dieser kurzen Erzählung habe ich die umständlichere des Lysias verbunden und zur weiteren Ausführung andere Stellen benutzt. Ich selbst habe natürlich binzufügen müssen, was zur Verbindung der gegebenen Theile nöthig war; aber ich hoffe nichts eingemischt zu haben, was dem Gemälde die antike Färbung rauben könnte. — Manches wird sich übrigens in dem Excurse, Anderes in den folgenden Anmerkungen gerechtfertigt finden.
